DeregistrationReasonOtherText: Quantity of regulatory substance was erroneously calculated for initial RMP

_desc.NAICS_DESCRIPTION: Nonferrous Metal (except Copper and Aluminum) Rolling, Drawing, and Extruding
Other Communication and Energy Wire Manufacturing

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
TECHNIC ENGINEERED POWDER DIVISION
RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN ? AMMONIA
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

Technic's Engineered Powders Division (Technic) manufactures metal powders for the electronics, electrical, jewelry, aerospace, medical, and dental industries.  Manufactured powders and flakes are used in a wide range of applications, including conductive adhesives, shielding, conductive inks, electrical contacts, solar cells, fuel cells, and batteries.  

As part of the metal powder manufacturing process, Technic uses aqueous ammonia at a concentration of 28%.  In the past, aqueous ammonia was stored in 55-gallon drums that were delivered to the facility as needed (at an onsite capacity up to 7,000 lbs.).  The installation of an aboveground ammonia tank eliminates the need for the drum storage, but increases the onsite ammonia storage capacity above the threshold quantity (20,000 lbs.) in 40 C.F.R. 68 for aqueous ammonia planning.  Although installation of the tank minimizes the potential for spills due to container transfer and daily use, there is an increased risk of a larger release from the tank.  This release potential is addressed in this RMP.

Technic has determined that the facility is subject to the Program Level 1 RMP requirements for the following reasons:

?    The worst-case offsite consequence analysis demonstrates that there will be no public receptors within the distance to toxic endpoint.
?    Technic has had no aqueous ammonia process-specific accidents with offsite consequences within the past five years.
?    Technic has coordinated emergency response with local responders.
?    OSHA PSM is not applicable because the ammonia concentration is less than 44%.
?    Technic?s NAICS is 331491 (SIC 33556) which is not one of the RMP-listed codes.

Accident History 

Technic has had no specific aqueous ammonia process-specific accidents with offsite consequences within the past five years.

Worst-Case Consequence Analysis

ALOHA software was used in conducting the worst-case offsite c

onsequence analysis and determining the distance to toxic endpoint.  The following assumptions were used:

?    A maximum of 38,718 lbs of aqueous ammonia, which is the working capacity of the tank, could be released instantaneously.  Although the tank is 6,000 gallons (43,020 lbs), Technic has administrative controls in place to limit the working capacity to 90% of the total tank capacity.
?    28% aqueous ammonia will be used.  
?    The volume of the puddle that could be formed is 703 cu. ft.  
?    The entire spill would be contained by the diked area, which is constructed of stress-relieved, chemical resistant polypropylene with welded seams.  The diked area has approximately 8,491gallons capacity [(7.67 ft. x 37 ft. x 4 ft). x (7.48 gal/cu.ft)] and a 283.79 sq. ft. surface area (i.e., puddle area).
?    The building surrounding the tank is designed for protection from the elements, and has a 357.79 sq. ft. floor area (9.67 ft. x 37 ft.).  Although the main doors of the building can be opened during a release, Technic has established administrative controls that require the enclosure doors to remain closed during a spill event, unless it is essential to response/cleanup.  The only remaining escape for vapors would be through the emergency vents/fan located high on the walls of the enclosure.
?    The area surrounding the facility is urban.
?    The wind speed was assumed to be 1.5 meters per second measured at a height of ten meters.
?    Consistent with OCA Guidance, it was assumed that 10% of the ammonia vapors could be released during a spill event.  
?    Partly cloudy conditions, with a wind speed of 1.5 m/sec from the southwest at ten meters above ground were assumed.  
?    The highest daily maximum temperature and average humidity from October 2005-October 2007 was used (100?F and as 65% relative humidity, respectively).  

The resulting release rate is 19.2 lbs/min, limited to a duration of one hour.  ALOHA does not allow for direct source modeling for solutions of ammonia nor does

it allow adjustments of the percentage of vapors released during a spill event.  Rather, it assumes an open air puddle release.  As such, ALOHA overestimates the vapor releases for scenarios such as the one presented at Technic.  The actual release rate and calculated distance to endpoint would be expected to be lower than that predicted using ALOHA.

The resulting estimated distances to the toxic endpoint of 0.14mg/l is 102 yards (0.058 miles).

Public and Environmental Receptors

To confirm there were no environmental or public receptors, Technic was located on a topographic map.  A circle was drawn around the ammonia tank?s planned location, with a radius equal to the distance to toxic endpoint.  There are no environmental receptors (national parks, state parks, monuments, wilderness areas, forests) or offsite public receptors (residences, institutions, industrial/commercial/office buildings, parks, recreational areas) within the distance to toxic endpoint.

The general public is not granted routine access to the site and there are no onsite locations that would be of interest as a gathering location.  For security measures, Technic employs the services of a security guard at the reception area and does not allow unaccompanied visitors at the site.  The area surrounding the manufacturing building and parking areas is mostly vegetated.  Park East Drive is south-southwest of Technic?s main parking area.  

Emergency Response

Technic has developed a relationship with local emergency planning personnel to ensure that the facility is adequately prepared in the event of a release.  The Woonsocket Fire Department serves as the LEPC, and has been made familiar with the ammonia process at the site.  In addition, Technic has regularly reported ammonia storage on its Tier 2 reports, as required by regulation.

Technic has the following plans and programs in place at the facility:

?    Emergency Response Plan ? Addresses coordination with agencies, emergency recognition and

prevention, lines of authority, communication, security, evacuation, emergency response and cleanup procedures;
?    Hazardous Waste Contingency Plan ? Addresses response elements related to identification and cleanup of hazardous waste, including those that may result from a spill event;
?    Emergency Action Plan ? Provides procedures for reporting emergencies, including evacuation procedures; and
?    HAZCOM training program ? Provides employees the necessary background to identify workplace hazards, interpret MSDS and labels, obtain personal protection equipment, and have a general awareness of emergency procedures for the site.

Technic personnel are trained to the First Responder Awareness Level [ref. 29 C.F.R. 1910.120(q)(6)(i)].  They do not respond to spills beyond the incidental level.  For all spills that are not incidental in nature, Technic would call upon the services of a spill response contractor (e.g., Clean Harbors).  

RMP Review and Update

At least once every five years, or with significant changes that affect the potential for ammonia discharge, Technic will:

?    Review and update, if necessary, the worst-case consequence analysis
?    Review and update, if necessary,  the emergency response program, including notification procedures and contacts
?    Coordinate with local officials, as appropriate
?    Notify Technic responders of any changes to your emergency response plan, as appropriate

Updates or corrections to the RMP will be filed:

?    Immediately upon determining information provided to EPA was inaccurate
?    Within six months of an accidental release of a regulated substance from a covered process that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known off-site deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage
?    Within six months of changes to your emergency response plan

All elements required by regulation shall be included in the RMP re-submission, which should be sent to the followi

ng address:  

By mail:
Risk Management Plan (RMP) Reporting Center
P.O. Box 1515
Lanham-Seabrook, Maryland 20703-1515

By courier or FEDEX:
Risk Management Plan (RMP) Reporting Center
c/o CSC
Suite 300
8400 Corporate Drive
New Carrollton, Maryland 20785

Additional information and program updates regarding the RMP program and submissions can be found at http://yosemite.epa.gov/oswer/ceppoweb.nsf/content/index.html.
